docs.lead_paragraph: State senators returned to Albany today for a one-day session, but left untouched several major pieces of proposed legislation, including increases in the minimum wage and workers' compensation, a revision of the Rockefeller drug laws, a requirement that priests report suspected child abuse and protection of gay men and lesbians from discrimination. But Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Senate leader, held out hope that the Senate, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Gov. George E. Pataki could yet resolve some of those issues. The Senate did approve several bills that the governor and the Assembly have agreed to, including one that would forbid the use of state money to fight or encourage unions, one that extends $2,000 tax credits for certain hybrid vehicles, and an anti-sweatshop bill that requires the state to buy uniforms produced under fair-labor practices.

headline.main: Some Unfinished Business Remains for Legislature in Albany

docs.abstract: New York State senators return to Albany for one-day session, but leave untouched some major pieces of proposed legislation; despite unfinished business, Joseph L Bruno, Republican Senate leader, says session has been 'extraordinarily successful'; cites bill giving mayor control of public schools in New York City and women's health bill requiring health insurers to cover birth control and annual mammograms (M)

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Three decades after the National High Blood Pressure Education Program started saying that controlling high blood pressure saves lives, rates of hypertension are rising. In addition, the proportion of patients being treated -- or treated well enough to bring their blood pressure readings under control -- is falling, creating waves of alarm among cardiovascular specialists.

headline.main: Methods Are Many to Reduce Blood Pressure

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on factors contributing to rise in stroke rates and leveling off of heart attack rates, both of which are directly linked to uncontrolled hypertension; factors include increase in number of overweight or obsese Americans, lack of symptoms, unwillingness or inability to make diet, exercise and lifestyle changes, lack of interest in drug therapy by patients and doctors and insurance-dictated constraints on doctors; offers advice on tailoring treatment; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Every time I read about a president having a medical procedure like the colonoscopy just performed on President Bush (front page, June 29), I wonder if he has any idea how many Americans can't afford this precautionary checkup.
docs.abstract: Alfred Gescheidt letter wonders if Pres Bush has any idea how many Americans cannot afford to have precautionary colonoscopies, as Bush just had (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Every time I read about a president having a medical procedure like the colonoscopy just performed on President Bush (front page, June 29), I wonder if he has any idea how many Americans can't afford this precautionary checkup.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We are dismayed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to renege on New York City's historical commitment to provide health benefits for Queens bus drivers (news article, June 25). Health benefits are increasingly under attack by American employers, and cutbacks in these benefits are the most common reason for strikes. This underscores the need for national health insurance, covering everyone.
docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Oliver Fein and Joanne Landy expresses dismay at Mayor Michael Bloomberg's proposal to renege on New York City's historical commitment to provide health benefits for Queens bus drivers, and calls on him to return to bargaining table with TWU (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical industry has sued the Bush administration, challenging its approval of state Medicaid laws that try to save money by restricting access to higher-cost prescription drugs. At issue is a Michigan program approved in January by Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services. A major purpose of the program is to extract discounts from prescription drug manufacturers.

headline.main: Drug Industry Sues Over Limiting Medicaid Costs

docs.abstract: Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, trade association for drug companies, sues Bush administration, challenging its approval of state Medicaid laws that try to save money by restricting access to higher-cost prescription drugs; at issue is Michigan program approved by Health and Human Services Department that penalizes drug companies unless they give state extra discounts beyond 15 percent reduction ordinarily required under Medicaid (M)
